name: CAS
description: Starts and manages your SAS Cloud Analytic Services session.
help:
Form 1: 
CAS  session-name  <options>;
Form 2: 
CAS  _ALL_ LIST | _ALL_ TERMINATE

arguments.name: session-name
arguments.description: specifies a valid SAS name that is less than 256 characters.

arguments.name: _ALL_
arguments.description: specifies that the LIST or TERMINATE argument that follows applies to all of the sessions in the SAS client.

arguments.name: ADDFMTLIB
arguments.description: adds a session format library.
arguments.help:
ADDFMTLIB FMTLIBNAME=*format-library-name* <*option(s)*>
ADDFMTLIB TABLE=*table-name* <CASLIB=*caslib*> <FMTLIBNAME=*format-library-name*> <*option(s)*>
ADDFMTLIB PATH=*path* <FMTLIBNAME=*format-library-name*> <*option(s)*>

arguments.name: FMTLIBNAME=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the format library to add.

arguments.name: TABLE=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the table where the format library was previously saved using SAVEFMTLIB.

arguments.name: table-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the table in which the format library is saved.

arguments.name: CASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the caslib where the table is saved.

arguments.name: PATH=
arguments.description: specifies the absolute path to the file in which the format information is stored.

arguments.name: POSITION=
arguments.description: specifies the position of this format library in the format-library search list.

arguments.name: APPEND
arguments.description: appends this format library to the end of the format-library search list.

arguments.name: INSERT
arguments.description: inserts this format library at the beginning of the format-library search list.

arguments.name: REPLACE
arguments.description: replaces the current format-library search list with this format library.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: does not add this format library to the format-library search list.

arguments.name: PROMOTE
arguments.description: promotes the format library to global scope so that it is available to all sessions.

arguments.name: REPLACEFMTLIB
arguments.description: replaces the format library if it already exists.

arguments.name: AUTHDOMAIN=
arguments.description: obtains credentials from the SAS Viya credentials service.

arguments.name: authentication-domain
arguments.description: specifies the name of an authentication domain object registered on the SAS Viya credentials service that associates user credentials with an identity. The domain name can be specified with or without quotation marks.

arguments.name: AUTHINFO=
arguments.description: specifies an authinfo file or netrc file that includes authentication information.

arguments.name: CASSERVERMD=
arguments.description: specifies the name of a server object registered on the SAS Metadata Server that associates SAS Cloud Analytic Services connection parameters with a server name.

arguments.name: DISCONNECT
arguments.description: disconnects SAS from the session.

arguments.name: DROPFMTLIB
arguments.description: drops a session-scope or a global-scope format library.

arguments.name: FMTLIBNAME=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the format library to drop.

arguments.name: FMTSEARCHREMOVE
arguments.description: removes the format library from the format search list.

arguments.name: FMTSEARCH=
arguments.description: modifies the format library search list for the session.

arguments.name: (name1 name2nameN)
arguments.description: specifies a list of one or more format-library names enclosed in parentheses.

arguments.name: POSITION=
arguments.description: specifies the position of the format libraries in the format-library search list.

arguments.name: APPEND
arguments.description: appends the format libraries to the end of the format-library search list.

arguments.name: INSERT
arguments.description: inserts the format libraries at the beginning of the format-library search list.

arguments.name: REPLACE
arguments.description: replaces the current format-library search list with the specified format libraries.

arguments.name: FMTSEARCH
arguments.description: clears the format library search list for the session.

arguments.name: HOST=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the CAS service running in the SAS Viya Kubernetes framework.

arguments.name: LIST
arguments.description: writes to the SAS log information about a single session or all of the sessions in your SAS client.

arguments.name: LISTABOUT
arguments.description: writes information about SAS Cloud Analytic Services to the SAS log.

arguments.name: LISTFMTRANGES
arguments.description: lists the ranges and labels for a format.

arguments.name: FMTNAME=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the format to list.

arguments.name: LISTFMTSEARCH
arguments.description: displays the format library search list for the session.

arguments.name: LISTFORMATS
arguments.description: lists the user-defined format libraries that are known to SAS.

arguments.name: FMTLIBNAME=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the format library.

arguments.name: SCOPE=
arguments.description: specifies the scope.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: lists both SESSION and GLOBAL format libraries that are known to SAS.

arguments.name: SESSION
arguments.description: lists the format libraries that are known to SAS.

arguments.name: GLOBAL
arguments.description: lists the format libraries that are known globally to all SAS sessions.

arguments.name: MEMBERS
arguments.description: lists the names of the members in each format library.

arguments.name: LISTHISTORY
arguments.description: prints the log of actions that were generated by statements and procedures and submitted to the CAS session.

arguments.name: history_count
arguments.description: specifies the number of the most recent actions that are to be listed.

arguments.name: _ALL_
arguments.description: lists all of the actions that have been executed in the current session.

arguments.name: LISTSERVERSTARTOPTS
arguments.description: lists the SAS Cloud Analytic Services options and their current values.

arguments.name: LISTSESSIONS
arguments.description: writes to the SAS log information about all of the current user's sessions that are known to SAS Cloud Analytic Services.

arguments.name: LISTSESSOPTS
arguments.description: lists the session options.

arguments.name: PORT=
arguments.description: specifies the port on which the CAS Kubernetes service listens for client connections.

arguments.name: PROMOTEFMTLIB
arguments.description: promotes a session-local format library to a global format library.

arguments.name: FMTLIBNAME=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the format library.

arguments.name: REPLACE
arguments.description: replaces the format library if it is already promoted.

arguments.name: RECONNECT
arguments.description: reconnects to a session using a session name.

arguments.name: SAVEFMTLIB
arguments.description: saves a session format library to a CAS table or to a file.

arguments.name: FMTLIBNAME=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the format library to save.

arguments.name: CASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies the caslib in which the table is stored.

arguments.name: TABLE=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the table in which the format library is saved.

arguments.name: PROMOTE
arguments.description: promotes the format library to global scope so that it is available to all sessions.

arguments.name: REPLACE
arguments.description: replaces the table in the caslib if it already exists.

arguments.name: PATH=
arguments.description: specifies the absolute path to the file in which the format library is to be saved.

arguments.name: SESSOPTS=
arguments.description: specifies one or more session option settings to apply during or after session start-up.

arguments.name: TERMINATE
arguments.description: terminates a single connected or disconnected session, or all of the connected and disconnected sessions in your SAS client.

arguments.name: USER=
arguments.description: specifies the user ID to use for connecting to SAS Cloud Analytic Services.

arguments.name: UUID=
arguments.description: specifies the UUID of an existing session to which you want to connect.

arguments.name: UUIDMAC=
arguments.description: specifies a SAS macro variable name into which the UUID of the session is stored.

name: CASLIB
description: Adds and manages caslibs in a SAS Cloud Analytic Services session.
help:
Form 1: 
CASLIB              caslib-reference-name 
           <SESSREF=session-reference>             <DATASOURCE=(SRCTYPE="type"                      <data-source-options>                ) >
	<PATH="directory-path"><options>;
Form 2: 
CASLIB              caslib-reference-name 
           LIST             <SESSREF=session-reference> ;
Form 3: 
CASLIB              _ALL_ ASSIGN |         
       _ALL_ LIST 
           <SESSREF=session-reference>;

arguments.name: caslib-reference-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the caslib. Names of session caslibs must be unique within the session. Names of global caslibs must be unique across all sessions within a server.

arguments.name: ASSIGN
arguments.description: used with the _ALL_ option to assign SAS librefs for existing caslibs so that they are visible in the SAS Studio Libraries tree.

arguments.name: _ALL_
arguments.description: specifies that the ASSIGN, or LIST argument applies to all currently added caslibs.

arguments.name: CREATEDIRECTORY
arguments.description: creates a subdirectory in the caslib's data source. The path, up to the last directory, must already exist.

arguments.name: DATASOURCE=
arguments.description: specifies data source options to use when connecting to a data source. The SRCTYPE="type" option specifies the data source type. Data sources can be either databases or path-based. The data-source-options syntax depends on the data source.

arguments.name: ENCRYPTIONDOMAIN=
arguments.description: specifies the name for a collection of data that is stored with a common encryption password.

arguments.name: ENCRYPTIONPASSWORD=
arguments.description: specifies a password for encrypting or decrypting stored data.

arguments.name: DESCRIPTION=
arguments.description: specifies a description of the data source.

arguments.name: DROP
arguments.description: drops a session scope caslib.

arguments.name: GLOBAL
arguments.description: adds the caslib so that it has global scope. For a global-scope caslib, you can set access controls so that it is accessible from all sessions and can be a way to share data. Other connections to the server that get their own sessions have access to the caslib, subject to access controls. If you do not specify GLOBAL, the caslib is created with session scope. You must also grant access to the caslib in the CAS Server Monitor. You can add caslibs only if you are authorized to do so. See .

arguments.name: LIBREF=
arguments.description: creates a libref and associates it with a caslib. The libref can then be used to access data in SAS Cloud Analytic Services.

arguments.name: LIST
arguments.description: displays caslib names and their specifications. To display all caslibs, specify _ALL_ for the caslib-reference-name .

arguments.name: NOTACTIVE
arguments.description: specifies that the caslib being added does not become the active caslib for the session.

arguments.name: PATH=
arguments.description: specifies the fully qualified path to a directory to use as a data source.

arguments.name: SESSION
arguments.description: adds the caslib so that it is session-scope. Other connections to the server that get their own sessions do not have access to the caslib. The lifetime of the caslib is the lifetime of the session. When you add caslibs, SESSION is the default.

arguments.name: SESSREF=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the session to associate the caslib with. By default, the most recently started session is used.

arguments.name: SUBDIRS
arguments.description: specifies that subdirectories of the specified PATH= directory can be accessed with the caslib.

name: DECLARE
description: Declares an ODS object and creates an instance of and initializes data for an ODS object.

arguments.name: ODSOUT
arguments.description: is the class name.

arguments.name: object-reference
arguments.description: specifies the object reference name for the ODS object.

instantiates the ODS object. As an alternative to the two-step process of using the DECLARE statement and the _NEW_ operator to declare and instantiate an ODS object, you can use the DECLARE statement to declare and instantiate the ODS object in one step. For example, in the following line of code, the DECLARE statement declares and instantiates an ODS object and assigns it to the object reference obj:

name: ENDRSUBMIT
description: Marks the end of a block of statements that a client session submits to a server session for execution.

arguments.name: CANCEL
arguments.description: This option is useful in an interactive line mode session if you see an error in a previously entered statement, and you want to cancel the step.

name: KILLTASK
description: For asynchronous tasks, forces one or more active tasks or server sessions to terminate immediately.

arguments.name: _ALL_
arguments.description: terminates all active asynchronous tasks.

arguments.name: task
arguments.description: terminates a specific task by a name that corresponds to the server-ID that is associated with the CONNECTREMOTE= option in the RSUBMIT statement.

name: LISTTASK
description: Lists all active connections or tasks and identifies the execution status of each connection or task.

arguments.name: _ALL_
arguments.description: provides status information about all current tasks.

arguments.name: task
arguments.description: provides status information for the specified task. Identifies the specific task by a name that corresponds to the server-ID that is associated with the CONNECTREMOTE= option in the RSUBMIT or SIGNON statement.

name: RGET
description: Retrieves the log and output that are created by an asynchronous RSUBMIT and merges them into the Log and Output windows of the client session.

arguments.name: CONNECTREMOTE=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the server session that generated the spooled log and output to be retrieved. If only one session is active, server-ID can be omitted. If multiple server sessions are active and the option is omitted, the spooled log and output statements from the most recently accessed server session are retrieved and merged into the client Log and Output windows. You can find out which server session is the current session by examining the value that is assigned to the CONNECTREMOTE system option.

name: RSPT
description: Statements used for remote SQL pass-through.

arguments.name: SERVER=
arguments.description: identifies the name of the SAS server. If the SAS/CONNECT single-user server is used, server-ID specifies the server session. In either case, server-ID should be the same name that is specified in the SERVER= option in a LIBNAME statement.

arguments.name: SAPW=
arguments.description: specifies the password for controlling user access to a multi-user server as specified in the UAPW= option in the PROC SERVER statement. If UAPW= is specified when the server is started, you must specify SAPW= in a CONNECT TO REMOTE statement that specifies that server.

arguments.name: DBMS=
arguments.description: identifies the remote DBMS to connect to. This is the same name that you would specify in a CONNECT TO statement if you were connecting directly to the DBMS. This option is used if you want to connect to a remote DBMS instead of the remote SAS SQL processor.

arguments.name: PT2DBPW=
arguments.description: specifies the password for controlling pass-through access to remote DBMS databases that are specified by using the PT2DBPW= option in the PROC SERVER statement. If PT2DBPW= is specified when the server is started, you must specify PT2DBPW= in a CONNECT TO REMOTE statement that specifies the same server and specifies DBMS=.

arguments.name: DBMSARG=
arguments.description: specifies the arguments that are required by the remote DBMS to establish the connection. These are the same arguments that you would specify in a CONNECT TO statement if you were connecting directly to the DBMS.

arguments.name: FROM
arguments.description: specifies the connection to the remote SAS SQL processor or the remote DBMS as the source of data for the SELECT statement and the recipient of the dbms-query. For remote SAS data that is accessed through the PROC SQL view engine, dbms-query is any valid SELECT statement in PROC SQL. For a remote DBMS, dbms-query is the same SQL query that you would specify if you were connected directly to the DBMS.

arguments.name: alias
arguments.description: specifies the connection to the remote SAS SQL processor or the remote DBMS as the source of data for the SELECT statement and the recipient of the dbms-query. For remote SAS data that is accessed through the PROC SQL view engine, dbms-query is any valid SELECT statement in PROC SQL. For a remote DBMS, dbms-query is the same SQL query that you would specify if you were connected directly to the DBMS.

arguments.name: EXECUTE
arguments.description: specifies an SQL statement to be executed by the SAS SQL processor or by the remote DBMS in the server session. For remote SAS data that is accessed through the PROC SQL view engine, SQL-statement is any valid PROC SQL statement except SELECT. For a remote DBMS that is accessed through a single-user server in a SAS/CONNECT session, SQL-statement is the same SQL statement that you would specify if you were connected directly to the DBMS. For a remote DBMS, this statement might not be used if the DBMS is accessed through a remote multi-user server.

arguments.name: alias;
arguments.description: specifies an SQL statement to be executed by the SAS SQL processor or by the remote DBMS in the server session. For remote SAS data that is accessed through the PROC SQL view engine, SQL-statement is any valid PROC SQL statement except SELECT. For a remote DBMS that is accessed through a single-user server in a SAS/CONNECT session, SQL-statement is the same SQL statement that you would specify if you were connected directly to the DBMS. For a remote DBMS, this statement might not be used if the DBMS is accessed through a remote multi-user server.

arguments.name: DISCONNECT
arguments.description: ends the connection to the remote DBMS or to the SAS SQL processor in the server session.

arguments.name: alias;
arguments.description: ends the connection to the remote DBMS or to the SAS SQL processor in the server session.

name: RSUBMIT
description: Marks the beginning of a block of statements that a client session submits to a server session for execution.

arguments.name: CMACVAR=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the macro variable in which SAS stores a code indicating the state of the current RSUBMIT. When an RSUBMIT is executed, SAS checks the state of the RSUBMIT and stores a return code of 0, 1, or 2 in the specified CMACVAR variable.

arguments.name: CONNECTPERSIST=
arguments.description: specifies whether a connection persists (continues) or is automatically terminated after an RSUBMIT has completed. A connection results from a sign–on to the server session.

arguments.name: CONNECTREMOTE=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the server session that the RSUBMIT statements are executed in. If only one session is active, server-ID can be omitted. If multiple server sessions are active, omitting this option causes the program statements to be run in the most recently accessed server session. You can specify server-ID using the following formats:

arguments.name: process-name
arguments.description: process-name is a descriptive name that you assign to the server session on a multiprocessor computer when the SASCMD= option is used.

arguments.name: computer-name
arguments.description: computer-name is the name of a computer that is running a Telnet daemon or that is running a spawner that is not specified as a service. If the computer name is longer than eight characters, a SAS macro variable name should be used.

arguments.name: computer-name.port-name
arguments.description: computer-name is the name of a server, and port-name is the name of the port that the spawner service runs on. If the computer name is longer than eight characters, assign the computer name to a SAS macro variable and use the macro variable name as the server ID.

arguments.name: computer-name.port-number
arguments.description:
computer-name is the name of a server, and port-number is the port that the spawner service runs on.
• when used in a WAITFOR  statement that is used to wait for the completion of an asynchronous statement in a remote submit.
• when used in a LIBNAME statement.

arguments.name: computer-with-port
arguments.description: computer-with-port is a macro variable that contains the name of a server and the port that the spawner service runs on, separated by one or more spaces. This specification is appropriate in cases where the server-ID must be specified as a one-level name.

arguments.name: computer-name._
arguments.description: computer-name is the name of a server and port-number is the port that the spawner service runs on.

arguments.name: CONNECTWAIT=
arguments.description: specifies whether RSUBMIT blocks execute synchronously or asynchronously. Synchronous RSUBMIT statements are executed sequentially. An RSUBMIT must be completed in the server session before control is returned to the client session.

arguments.name: CSYSRPUTSYNC=
arguments.description: specifies whether to synchronize the client session's macro variables when the client session receives results from the server session or when a synchronization point is encountered. Macro variables are updated in the client session using the %SYSRPUT macro in an asynchronous RSUBMIT.

arguments.name: INHERITLIB=
arguments.description: enables libraries that are defined in the client session to be inherited by the server session for Read and Write access. As an option, each client libref can be associated with a libref that is named differently in the server session. If the server libref is omitted, the client libref name is used in the server session. A space is used to separate each libref pair in a series, which is enclosed in parenthesis.

arguments.name: LOG=
arguments.description: directs the SAS log or the SAS output that is generated by the current server session to the backing store or to the specified file. A backing store is a SAS utility file that is written to the client SAS Work directory.

arguments.name: KEEP
arguments.description: spools log or output lines, as applicable, to the backing store or to the computer on which the client session is running. The log or output lines can be retrieved using the RGET, RSUBMIT CONNECTWAIT=YES, or SIGNOFF statements. This is the default.

arguments.name: PURGE
arguments.description: deletes all the log or output lines that are generated by the current server session. PURGE is used to save disk resources. If you do not need the data, you can use PURGE to remove large volumes of log or output data that are written to the backing store.

arguments.name: file-specification
arguments.description: specifies a file as the destination for the log or output lines. The file is opened for output at the beginning of the asynchronous RSUBMIT and is closed at the end of the asynchronous RSUBMIT. After the current RSUBMIT has completed, subsequent RSUBMIT log or output lines can be appended to the preceding RSUBMIT destination file using the LOG= or OUTPUT= options. If you specify the same filename for multiple RSUBMIT statements and you do not specify the NEW or MOD options, then the log data will be appended to the current file by default.

arguments.name: "filename
arguments.description: is the physical location of the SAS log file or the SAS output file. Enclose the filename in double or single quotation marks.

arguments.name: fileref
arguments.description: is a SAS name that is associated with the physical location of the SAS log file or the SAS output file.

arguments.name: NEW
arguments.description: specifies that the file will be opened for new log output. For example, if the file already exists from previous RSUBMIT sessions, it is deleted and re-created rather than appended to the current output log file.

arguments.name: OUTPUT=
arguments.description: directs the SAS log or the SAS output that is generated by the current server session to the backing store or to the specified file. A backing store is a SAS utility file that is written to the client SAS Work directory.

arguments.name: KEEP
arguments.description: spools log or output lines, as applicable, to the backing store or to the computer on which the client session is running. The log or output lines can be retrieved using the RGET, RSUBMIT CONNECTWAIT=YES, or SIGNOFF statements. This is the default.

arguments.name: PURGE
arguments.description: deletes all the log or output lines that are generated by the current server session. PURGE is used to save disk resources. If you do not need the data, you can use PURGE to remove large volumes of log or output data that are written to the backing store.

arguments.name: file-specification
arguments.description: specifies a file as the destination for the log or output lines. The file is opened for output at the beginning of the asynchronous RSUBMIT and is closed at the end of the asynchronous RSUBMIT. After the current RSUBMIT has completed, subsequent RSUBMIT log or output lines can be appended to the preceding RSUBMIT destination file using the LOG= or OUTPUT= options. If you specify the same filename for multiple RSUBMIT statements and you do not specify the NEW or MOD options, then the log data will be appended to the current file by default.

arguments.name: "filename
arguments.description: is the physical location of the SAS log file or the SAS output file. Enclose the filename in double or single quotation marks.

arguments.name: fileref
arguments.description: is a SAS name that is associated with the physical location of the SAS log file or the SAS output file.

arguments.name: NEW
arguments.description: specifies that the file will be opened for new log output. For example, if the file already exists from previous RSUBMIT sessions, it is deleted and re-created rather than appended to the current output log file.

arguments.name: NOCSCRIPT
arguments.description: specifies that no script file should be used for sign-on. NOCSCRIPT accelerates sign-on and conserves memory resources.

arguments.name: PASSWORD=
arguments.description: specifies the password to use in order to sign on to a server session. The operating environment that the server session runs under can affect password naming conventions.

arguments.name: password
arguments.description: The value for this option is replaced by Xs in the log. To protect this password, you should use the security software at your site to limit access to the SAS program statements that create the server.

arguments.name: "encoded-password"
arguments.description: is an encoded version of a password. Using encoded passwords promotes security and enables you to store SAS programs that do not contain clear-text passwords.

arguments.name: SASCMD=
arguments.description: signs on to the server session on the same symmetric multiprocessing (SMP) computer that the client session is running on. This option is most useful when client and server sessions run on SMP hardware.

arguments.name: "SAS
arguments.description: Specifies the SAS command that is used to sign on to a server session.

arguments.name: !sascmd
arguments.description: Signs on to a server session by using the same command that was used to start the client session.

arguments.name: !sascmdv
arguments.description: Signs on to a server session by using the same command that was used to start the client session. The SAS invocation is written to the SAS log.

arguments.name: "host-command-file"
arguments.description: To execute additional commands before SAS is invoked, you can write a command file. The file extensions include .sh, .csh, and .ksh.

arguments.name: SIGNONWAIT=
arguments.description: specifies whether a sign-on to a server session is to be executed synchronously or asynchronously. You can sign on using the SIGNON statement or the AUTOSIGNON system option.

arguments.name: USERNAME=
arguments.description: specifies the user ID to be used when connecting to a server session.

arguments.name: user-ID
arguments.description: specifies the name to be used when using the RSUBMIT statement to submit code to a remote server session. For details about a valid user ID, see .

arguments.name: _PROMPT_
arguments.description: specifies that SAS prompt the user for a valid user ID. This value enforces security.

name: SIGNOFF
description: Ends the connection between a client session and a server session.

arguments.name: _ALL_
arguments.description: ends all client/server connections running in parallel.

arguments.name: CMACVAR=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the macro variable to associate with the sign-off. When CMACVAR= is specified, SAS generates a return code that provides information about the state of the sign-off. Except for this condition, the macro variable is set after the SIGNOFF statement is completed.

arguments.name: CONNECTREMOTE=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the server session that you want to sign off from. If only one session is active, server-ID can be omitted. If multiple server sessions are active, omitting this option signs off the most recently accessed server session. You can find out which server session is current by examining the value assigned to the CONNECTREMOTE= system option.

arguments.name: server-ID
arguments.description: specifies the name of the server session that you want to sign off from. If only one session is active, server-ID can be omitted. If multiple server sessions are active, omitting this option signs off the most recently accessed server session. You can find out which server session is current by examining the value assigned to the CONNECTREMOTE= system option.

arguments.name: CSCRIPT=
arguments.description: specifies the script file to be used during sign-off. CSCRIPT can be specified as a fileref or a fully qualified pathname that is enclosed in parenthesis. If multiple CSCRIPT= options are specified, the last specification takes precedence.

arguments.name: fileref
arguments.description: is the name of the reference file that is associated with the script that ends the connection. A previously executed FILENAME statement must define the fileref.

arguments.name: 'filespec'
arguments.description: is the name of the SAS/CONNECT script that you want to execute. If you have not defined a fileref for the script that you want to execute, use the filespec in the SIGNOFF statement. The filespec can be either a fully qualified filename or the name of a file in the current working directory.

arguments.name: NOCSCRIPT
arguments.description: specifies that no SAS/CONNECT script should be used for sign-off. NOCSCRIPT is useful if you have defined the RLINK fileref but do not want to use it during sign-off. NOCSCRIPT accelerates sign-off and saves memory resources.

name: SIGNON
description: Initiates a connection between a client session and a server session.

arguments.name: CMACVAR=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the macro variable in which SAS stores a code indicating the state of the current sign-on. When a SIGNON is executed, SAS checks the state of the sign-on and stores a return code of 0, 1, or 2 in the specified CMACVAR variable. The return code is generated after SIGNON processing is complete and the name that you specify becomes the default name for the current server session. The CMACVAR macro variable can then be programmatically queried to learn the processing status of the sign-on (completed, failed, or in progress). See for a description of what each return code means.

arguments.name: CONNECTREMOTE=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the server session that you want to sign on to. If only one session is active, server-ID can be omitted. If multiple server sessions are active, omitting this option causes the program statements to be run in the most recently accessed server session. The current server session is identified by the value that is assigned to the CONNECTREMOTE system option.

arguments.name: process-name
arguments.description: process-name is a descriptive name that you assign to the server session on a multiprocessor computer when the SASCMD= option is used.

arguments.name: computer-name
arguments.description: computer-name is the name of a computer that is running a Telnet daemon or that is running a spawner that is not specified as a service. If the computer name is longer than eight characters, a SAS macro variable name should be used.

arguments.name: computer-name.port-name
arguments.description: computer-name is the name of a server, and port-name is the name of the port that the spawner service runs on. If the computer name is longer than eight characters, assign the computer name to a SAS macro variable and use the macro variable name as the server ID.

arguments.name: computer-name.port-number
arguments.description:
computer-name is the name of a server, and port-number is the port that the spawner service runs on.
• when used in a WAITFOR  statement that is used to wait for the completion of an asynchronous RSUBMIT.
• when used in a LIBNAME statement.

arguments.name: computer-with-port
arguments.description: computer-with-port is a macro variable that contains the name of a server and the port that the spawner service runs on, separated by one or more spaces. This specification is appropriate in cases where the server-ID must be specified as a one-level name.

arguments.name: computer-name._
arguments.description: computer-name is the name of a server and port-number is the port that the spawner service runs on. This format should be used to specify the server-ID value for the SERVER= option in a LIBNAME statement.

arguments.name: CONNECTSTATUS=
arguments.description: specifies whether the Transfer Status window is displayed for file transfers within the current server session.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that the Transfer Status window is displayed for file transfers within the current server session.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that the Transfer Status window is not displayed for file transfers within the current server session.

arguments.name: CONNECTWAIT=
arguments.description: specifies whether RSUBMIT blocks execute synchronously or asynchronously. Synchronous RSUBMIT statements are executed sequentially. An RSUBMIT must be completed in the server session before control is returned to the client session.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that the RSUBMIT blocks execute synchronously.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that the RSUBMIT blocks execute asynchronously.

arguments.name: CSCRIPT=
arguments.description: specifies the SAS/CONNECT script file to be used during sign-on.

arguments.name: ”filename”
arguments.description: specifies the name of the script file or specifies the name of the script file along with its location (pathname). Enclose the filename and fully qualified filename in double or single quotation marks.

arguments.name: “fully-qualified-filename"
arguments.description: specifies the name of the script file or specifies the name of the script file along with its location (pathname). Enclose the filename and fully qualified filename in double or single quotation marks.

arguments.name: fileref
arguments.description: is the name of the reference file that is associated with the script file. A previously executed FILENAME statement must define the fileref.

arguments.name: "SASSCRIPT-specification"
arguments.description: is the physical location of the SAS/CONNECT script file in the directory that is specified by the SASSCRIPT system option.

arguments.name: CSYSRPUTSYNC=
arguments.description: specifies whether to synchronize the client session's macro variables when the client session receives results from the server session or when a synchronization point is encountered. Macro variables are updated in the client session using the %SYSRPUT macro in a SIGNON statement.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that the client session's macro variables will be updated when the client receives the results of the server session's execution of the %SYSRPUT macro. The results are delivered in the form of a packet. Specifying YES does not mean that the client's macro variables will be updated immediately after the server's execution of the %SYSRPUT macro variable. YES means that the client's macro variables will be updated when the client receives the packet from the server. Therefore, the exact time at which the client's macro variables are updated will depend on the availability of the client to receive the packet. If the client is busy, the server will wait until the client session is ready to receive the packet.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that the client session's macro variables will be updated when a synchronization point is encountered. This is the default.

arguments.name: INHERITLIB=
arguments.description: enables libraries that are defined in the client session to be inherited by the server session for Read and Write access. Also, each client libref can be associated with a libref that is named differently in the server session. A space is used to separate each libref pair in a series, which is enclosed in parentheses.

arguments.name: LOG=
arguments.description: Used only when NOSIGNONWAIT is in effect, these options direct the SAS log or the SAS output that is generated by the current server session to the backing store or to a file specification. A backing store is a SAS utility file that is written to disk in the client SAS Work library.

arguments.name: KEEP
arguments.description: spools log or output lines, as applicable, to the backing store or to the computer on which the client session is running. The log or output lines can be retrieved using the RGET, RSUBMIT CONNECTWAIT=YES, or SIGNOFF statement. This is the default.

arguments.name: PURGE
arguments.description: deletes all the log or output lines that are generated by the current server session. PURGE is used to save disk resources. If you do not need the data, you can use PURGE to remove large volumes of log or output data that are written to the backing store.

arguments.name: file-specification
arguments.description: specifies a file as the destination for the log or output lines. The file is opened for output at the beginning of the asynchronous SIGNON and is closed at the end of the asynchronous SIGNON. After the current SIGNON has completed, subsequent SIGNON log or output lines can be appended to the preceding SIGNON destination file using the LOG= or OUTPUT= options.

arguments.name: "filename
arguments.description: is the physical location of the SAS log file or the SAS output file. Enclose the filename in double or single quotation marks.

arguments.name: fileref
arguments.description: is a SAS name that is associated with the physical location of the SAS log file or the SAS output file.

arguments.name: NEW
arguments.description: specifies that a new file is to be opened for output. If the file already exists, then it is deleted and re-created. NEW is not the default.

arguments.name: OUTPUT=
arguments.description: Used only when NOSIGNONWAIT is in effect, these options direct the SAS log or the SAS output that is generated by the current server session to the backing store or to a file specification. A backing store is a SAS utility file that is written to disk in the client SAS Work library.

arguments.name: KEEP
arguments.description: spools log or output lines, as applicable, to the backing store or to the computer on which the client session is running. The log or output lines can be retrieved using the RGET, RSUBMIT CONNECTWAIT=YES, or SIGNOFF statement. This is the default.

arguments.name: PURGE
arguments.description: deletes all the log or output lines that are generated by the current server session. PURGE is used to save disk resources. If you do not need the data, you can use PURGE to remove large volumes of log or output data that are written to the backing store.

arguments.name: file-specification
arguments.description: specifies a file as the destination for the log or output lines. The file is opened for output at the beginning of the asynchronous SIGNON and is closed at the end of the asynchronous SIGNON. After the current SIGNON has completed, subsequent SIGNON log or output lines can be appended to the preceding SIGNON destination file using the LOG= or OUTPUT= options.

arguments.name: "filename
arguments.description: is the physical location of the SAS log file or the SAS output file. Enclose the filename in double or single quotation marks.

arguments.name: fileref
arguments.description: is a SAS name that is associated with the physical location of the SAS log file or the SAS output file.

arguments.name: NEW
arguments.description: specifies that a new file is to be opened for output. If the file already exists, then it is deleted and re-created. NEW is not the default.

arguments.name: NOCSCRIPT
arguments.description: specifies that no SAS/CONNECT script file should be used for sign-on. NOCSCRIPT accelerates sign-on and conserves memory resources.

arguments.name: PASSWORD=
arguments.description: specifies the password to be used when connecting to a server. The operating environment that the server runs under can also affect password naming conventions. The value for password is replaced by Xs in the SAS log. To protect your password, use the security software at your site to limit access to the SAS program statements that create the server session.

arguments.name: password
arguments.description:
specifies a user-supplied password that meets the following requirements:
• can be up to 256 characters in length. 
• can contain uppercase and lowercase letters.
• can contain periods ( . ) and spaces.

arguments.name: "encoded-password"
arguments.description: specifies an encoded password that was created using the PWENCODE procedure. Using encoded passwords promotes security and enables you to store SAS programs that do not contain clear-text passwords. To obtain an encoded password, use the PWENCODE procedure and specify the clear-text password as the value for the IN= option in the PROC PWENCODE statement. To use the generated encrypted password in a SIGNON statement, specify the entire string, including the key, as the value for the PASSWORD= option.

arguments.name: SASCMD=
arguments.description: signs on to the server session on the same symmetric multiprocessing (SMP) computer that the client session is running on. This option is most useful when client and server sessions run on SMP hardware.

arguments.name: "SAS-command"
arguments.description: specifies a user-defined command that is used to start a SAS process. SAS/CONNECT adds the proper options to make the SAS session a SAS/CONNECT server session. The command file that starts the SAS session is specific to your operating environment. Linux extensions include .sh, .csh, and .ksh.

arguments.name: "!SASCMD"
arguments.description: signs on to a server session using the same command that was used to start the client session. For example, if the SAS client session was started using the command

arguments.name: "!SASCMDV"
arguments.description: signs on to a server session using the same command that was used to start the client session and writes the SAS invocation to the SAS log. The “!SASCMDV” value is identical to the “!SASCMD” option value except that it also writes the SAS invocation to the SAS log.

arguments.name: SIGNONWAIT=
arguments.description: specifies whether a sign-on to a server session is to be executed synchronously or asynchronously.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies synchronous sign-on. A synchronous sign-on causes the client session to wait until the sign-on to a server session has completed before control is returned to the client session for continued execution. YES is the default.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies an asynchronous sign-on. An asynchronous sign-on to a server session begins execution and control is returned to the client session immediately for continued execution. Asynchronous sign-on allows multiple tasks (including other sign-ons) to be executed in parallel. Asynchronous sign-ons reduce the total amount of time that would be used to execute individual sign-ons to multiple server sessions. Using the saved time, the client session can execute more statements.

arguments.name: TBUFSIZE=
arguments.description: specifies the size of the buffer that SAS/CONNECT uses for transferring data between a client session and a server session.

arguments.name: buffer-size-in-bytes
arguments.description: specifies the size of the buffer that SAS/CONNECT uses for transferring data. The value must be a number whose value is greater than 0 and is a multiple of 1024.

arguments.name: USERNAME=
arguments.description: specifies the user ID to be used when connecting to a server session. Here are the values that can be assigned to USERNAME=:

arguments.name: user-ID
arguments.description: specifies the name to be used when signing on. For details about a valid user ID, see .

name: WAITFOR
description: Causes the client session to wait for the completion of one or more tasks (asynchronous RSUBMIT statements) that are in progress.

arguments.name: _ANY_
arguments.description: causes the client session to wait for the completion of any of the specified tasks (a logical OR of the completion task states).

arguments.name: _ALL_
arguments.description: causes the client session to wait for the completion of all of the specified tasks (a logical AND of the completion task states).

arguments.name: task...taskn
arguments.description: identifies one or more asynchronous tasks to be completed. The task corresponds with the server–ID that is associated with the CONNECTREMOTE= option when the RSUBMIT is submitted.

arguments.name: TIMEOUT=
arguments.description: allots the interval, in seconds, to wait for one or more asynchronous tasks to complete. If the specified tasks have not completed by time-out, then the WAITFOR statement is terminated, control is returned to the client session, and the asynchronous tasks continue to execute until they are completed. The SYSRC system macro variable will have a nonzero status.
